thread.title: Double hit of asteroid plus volcanoes killed off dinosaurs, study says
thread.title_full: Double hit of asteroid plus volcanoes killed off dinosaurs, study says

author: Reuters
title: Double hit of asteroid plus volcanoes killed off dinosaurs, study says
text:
Dinosaur extinction was caused by asteroid and volcanoes, study says 'It's time to stop dismissing one cause or the other.... Both contributed,' geologist affirms Thomson Reuters Posted: Oct 02, 2015 5:14 PM ET Last Updated: Oct 02, 2015 5:14 PM ET It has long been debated among scientists what wiped out dinosaurs like the long-necked Qijianglong guokr seen here. A new paper in the journal Science has an answer. (University of Alberta) Related Stories Dinosaur museum in small-town Alberta hopes to hit the big time 
It was a combination of calamities — an asteroid strike followed by vast volcanic eruptions half a world away — that doomed the dinosaurs and many other creatures 66 million years ago, according to new research that wades into a decades-long scientific argument. 
Scientists said Thursday they have determined with new precision the proximity of the dates of the catastrophes: a space rock about 10 kilometres wide striking Mexico's Yucatan region and colossal eruptions in India. Cosmic chain reaction led to asteroid crash 
The two events roiled Earth by throwing dust, ash and harmful fumes like carbon dioxide and sulfur dioxide into the air, altering the climate and killing off about 75 per cent of all species in one of Earth's worst mass extinctions. 
The researchers said the asteroid strike occurred 66.04 million years ago, plus or minus about 30,000 years. 
They said volcanic eruptions in a region called the Deccan Traps were already underway at a lower intensity but dramatically accelerated after the asteroid strike as if the powerful impact triggered it. The dating method they used found this acceleration began within 50,000 years of the impact, but it could have been in the mere days, months or years afterward. 
"Within measurement error, they're simultaneous," said volcanologist Loÿc Vanderkluysen of Philadelphia's Drexel University. 
"The two processes in tandem caused the extinctions," added Paul Renne, director of the Berkeley Geochronology Center and a University of California, Berkeley, geologist, who led the study in the journal Science. 'Contentious' debate 
Scientists have debated for about 35 years which of the two disasters drove the extinction, some touting one while calling the other inconsequential. 
"The debate has been contentious," Renne said. "Now it's time to stop dismissing one cause or the other. They clearly happened at the same time and both contributed." 
"An asteroid 10 kilometres across, about the size of Manhattan, hitting the Earth is traumatic enough. But what followed were the largest volcanic eruptions the Earth had seen in 60 million years. And in their wake would have come 4,000 centuries of changing climate, ocean acidification and acid rains," Vanderkluysen added. 
The Deccan eruptions lasted 420,000 years after the asteroid and extruded enough lava to cover the equivalent of most of Canada, up to 180 metres. 
Canadian researchers have previously challenged the asteroid-impact theory of dinosaurs' extinction. A scientist at the Royal Tyrrell Museum in Alberta posited more than a decade ago that a period of global cooling that preceded the catastrophic impact drove temperatures low enough to make the reptiles vulnerable to being wiped out. With files from CBC News
